content.text:
> If you check `uname -a` you get the Arch version, while I think the Antergos AUR pkg has a version too.

```console
$ uname -a
Linux samus 4.18.14-arch1-1-ARCH #1 SMP PREEMPT Sat Oct 13 13:42:37 UTC 2018 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

Could you mean the [linux kernel](https://www.archlinux.org/packages/core/x86_64/linux/) version? If you're avoiding `pacman -Syu` then it might be a useful proxy for how behind your other packages are, but you can install new packages without upgrading your kernel.

> I'm not sure what you mean about versions not mattering. "Antergos does not support partial updates!"

I don't use Antergos, but you're right -- [partial upgrades are not supported](https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/System_maintenance#Partial_upgrades_are_unsupported), as everyone is assumed to be up-to-date via `pacman -Syu`.

> The concern is, if you need to install the software without it forcing a full system upgrade.

The "full system upgrade" is something that should happen regularly, and packages are built with the assumption that your system is up-to-date. If you get any errors during the installation process I'd be happy to hear about them, but Arch packages don't specify a version range for dependency compatibility. You can see the dependencies [here](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/patchbay), but the best way to test is to attempt an installation:

```sh
git clone https://aur.archlinux.org/patchbay.git
cd patchbay
makepkg -si
```

---

I think this might be getting a bit sidetracked from @mix's announcement, maybe we could start a new thread for this discussion about #archlinux?
